Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Infra-red Control of Electron Transfer Mechanisms
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this collaborative project funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics & Mechanisms B Program of the Chemistry Division, Professors David N. Beratan and Peng Zhang of the Department of Chemistry at Duke University and Professors Igor V. Rubtsov and Russell H. Schmehl of the Department of Chemistry at Tulane University are developing novel ways to control the flow of electrical charge through molecules. Electron transfer at the molecular scale is essential in naturally occurring reactions and in devices of technological significance. The ability to dial in the rate of electronic motion and to control the directionality of these reactions on the molecular scale is a significant challenge that could open up new strategies for solar energy conversion, for understanding of biological energy conversion schemes, and for developing new strategies for devices of technological significance. The project includes intensive collaborations among chemical synthesis, ultrafast spectroscopy, and theory to establish a very rich interdisciplinary training environment for students. The team is promoting science and education by providing summer research opportunities to economically-disadvantaged and historically underrepresented groups. In addition, novel curriculum developments involve multi-university, multi-faculty teaching of courses that address the chemical and physical principles underpinning the research.

The overall aim of the project is to understand the chemical and physical approaches that use infrared perturbations to control charge flow at the molecular scale. The research also includes the design of novel molecular structures where the charge flow is strongly influenced by the infra-red radiation. The project combines the power of theoretical and experimental approaches to manipulate charge flow in molecules. The researchers use ultrafast multi-pulse spectroscopic methods in the laboratory to drive and to perturb the reaction dynamics of donor-bridge-acceptor compounds. Several classes of donor-bridge-acceptor molecular systems are prepared and studied, including transition-metal complexes, bimetallic complexes, hydrogen-bonded systems, and systems with bi-stable bridges. Using newly developed methods of non-equilibrium molecular dynamics, the same molecular systems examined in the experimental laboratory are simulated, targeting the development of understanding vibrational excitation that may perturb both reaction coordinate motion and donor-acceptor electronic coupling interactions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Electron transfer (ET) plays a central role in science and engineering. The control of ET at the molecular scale is central to longer-term applications in solar energy conversion, molecular bioenergetics, and nanoscience.

This project is built upon our recent discoveries that infra-red (IR) excitation of molecular vibrational motion may be used to control the rate of ET reactions, as well as the competition between ET reactions and other processes that drain energy from molecules. The research, combining the power of theoretical and experimental approaches to manipulate ET reactions, aimed to understand the chemical and physical origins of ET rate changes that arise from IR excitation of these systems. In particular, the research focused on measuring and using the power of theoretical chemistry to understand the magnitude, sign, and physical origins of IR-perturbed ET effects in organic compounds as well as compounds containing transition metals.

In collaboration with researchers who used ultrafast spectroscopic methods in the laboratory, the theoretical team developed and implemented theoretical tools to understand how vibrational excitation of molecules changes ET rates and mechanisms. In particular, the researchers studied how IR excitation changes the nature of these ET reactions. The research defined the physical origins of IR perturbed ET kinetics that is observed experimentally and, more importantly, provided principles for the design of next generation molecular structures with ET processes that are susceptible to IR manipulation with improved selectivity and sensitively. Importantly, the physical insight derived from the project are not limited to ET reactions, the concepts can be applied as well to the IR control of other chemical reactions.

The broader impact of this NSF project is derived from the central role of ET reaction in science and engineering and the recently discovered ability of IR to manipulate the rates of ET reactions. The intensive interdisciplinary training environment for the students in the project was also noteworthy.

The intellectual merit of this undertaking arises from developing a physical understanding of how to manipulate the propagation of electrons on the nanometer length scale using vibrational excitation. The control of electronic motion on the molecular scale is central to longer-term applications in solar energy conversion, molecular bioenergetics, and nanoscience. While the quantum tunneling of electrons through molecules has been a topic of intensive investigation for 30 years, the ability to manipulate charge flow using a chemically innocent perturbation, namely IR irradiation, was discovered in this collaborative research project and is just a few years old. The research program derives intellectual merit through its charting of new schemes to control chemical reactivity through the vibrational excitation of reacting molecules. Further merit is generated from the intensive collaboration between theory and experiment to understand these fundamental but complex molecular phenomena in the condensed phase.
